q: What is epiglottitis and what are its symptoms?
a: Epiglottitis is inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis. Symptoms include a severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, difficulty breathing, high temperature, irritability, and restlessness.

q: When should I seek medical advice for epiglottitis?
a: Epiglottitis is a medical emergency, so you should call 999 for an ambulance if you think you or your child has it. Do not attempt to examine the throat or place anything inside the mouth while waiting for the ambulance.

q: How is epiglottitis treated?
a: Epiglottitis is treated in the hospital. The medical team will secure the airways, provide oxygen, and may perform a tracheostomy if necessary. Antibiotics will be given to treat any underlying infection.

q: What tests are done to diagnose epiglottitis?
a: Tests such as a fibreoptic laryngoscopy, throat swab, blood tests, and X-ray/CT scan may be done to diagnose epiglottitis.

q: What causes epiglottitis?
a: Epiglottitis is usually caused by an infection with Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) bacteria. Other causes can include bacterial or fungal infections, viral infections, trauma to the throat, and smoking.

q: How can epiglottitis be prevented?
a: The most effective way to prevent epiglottitis is to ensure vaccinations are up-to-date, especially the Hib vaccine. Hib vaccination is part of the 6-in-1 vaccine given to babies.

q: Is epiglottitis common?
a: Epiglottitis is rare in the UK, especially due to the success of the Hib vaccination program. Most cases now affect adults, and deaths from epiglottitis are rare.

q: How long does it take to recover from epiglottitis?
a: With prompt treatment, most people recover from epiglottitis after about a week and are able to leave the hospital within 5 to 7 days.

q: What are the main symptoms of epiglottitis in young children?
a: The main symptoms of epiglottitis in young children are breathing difficulties, stridor (high-pitched breathing sound), and a hoarse voice.

a: Hib bacteria spread through tiny droplets of saliva and mucus when an infected person coughs or sneezes. If these droplets are inhaled or come into contact with the face or mouth, it can cause an Hib infection, including epiglottitis.
